item.title: Tokenization Grand Prix Application - Etherfuse
item.dc:creator: etherfuse
item.description:
Grand Prix Application

I. Product Summary

  1. Project name

Etherfuse

  1. Product name

Stablebonds

  1. Product type / underlying asset

Short-term US Treasuries

  1. Issuer jurisdiction

Mexico City, Mexico

  1. Product website

https://app.etherfuse.com/

  1. Primary contact name, title, and method of contact

David Taylor, CEO dave@etherfuse.com

II. Company Details

  1. Company description

Etherfuse is a forward-thinking blockchain startup committed to transforming the financial landscape by integrating traditional finance and blockchain technology. Our mission is to bring access to financial assets by leveraging blockchain technology to lower barriers to ownership and empower individuals worldwide.

  1. Key personnel biographies

David Taylor - CEO and Founder

CEO of Etherfuse. 20+ years developing software and creating products. Launched multiple companies at JoyLabs. Engineering leader at Apple. VP of Engineering at Memo.

AJ Taylor - CTO and Founder

CTO of Etherfuse. VP of Engineering at Neural Payments. Previously the lead architect at Neural Payments, a P2P banking solution for credit unions. Expertise in backend-systems and payments.

  1. Team size

9 Employees

  1. Years in operation

3 Years

III. Product Information

  1. Describe the product

Weekly rebasing tokenized short-term US Treasuries called Stablebonds. Our Stablebond tokens accrue interest, allowing users to purchase and retain their yield like any other investment. By holding onto Stablebonds, token holders receive a guaranteed return from the government bond and the interest accrued on their token.

  1. Describe the underlying asset

All of our underlying assets are government-issued, short-term US treasuries that guarantee return for token holders. Our US Treasury bonds currently offer a 5% return.

  1. How is yield transferred to the token holder (i.e., via rebasing, distributions, price accrual, etc.) and how often?

Etherfuse tokenized bonds are interest-bearing tokens. Each week, upon bond issuance, tokens are automatically reinvested and accrue yield based on the interest of each bond. Users can divest and redeem their tokens anytime, which will be processed on the day of new issuances.

  1. What is the jurisdiction of the issuer and key entities?

Etherfuse is headquartered and regulated in Mexico City and operates in partnership with BBVA, Actinver, and Kuspit to maintain its reserves.

  1. What is the asset eligibility criteria and/or concentration limitations for the portfolio as defined by the underlying documents?

To mint and redeem directly from Etherfuse users must be KYC’d through our platform, SDK or contract. We currently do not offer our products to US persons or US companies.

  1. Are any hedging or derivatives permitted in the underlying portfolio?

Our tokens do not have any restrictions and a holder may interact with them freely. The underlying asset of the token is 1:1 with US treasuries.

  1. Provide a list of all counterparties and service providers used by your product (i.e., custodians, trustees, reporting agents, exchange agents, banks, etc). Provide flow-charts or diagrams for all related entities and counterparties, if available.

Actinver: Fitch AA & F1+

BBVA: Fitch AAA

Kuspit

  1. What is the AUM of the product? Provide a breakdown by blockchain

Solana 2MM

  1. What are the standard fees (i.e., subscription, redemption, management, etc.)?

.25% APY of AUM

  1. Other than the fees described above, can other expenses be paid from the proceeds of the product/assets?

There are no additional fees paid by yield earned.

  1. How is your product permissioned? (e.g., primary users, secondary users)

There are no restrictions, it is an SPL token.

12.What is the monthly transaction volume for the product?

As we are directly integrated with the stock exchange and our brokerages, we do not have any volume limitations. We can both mint and redeem any size weekly. The currency volume is around 200k USD weekly.

13.What is the expected and maximum time for users to subscribe to and redeem from your product? Have you had any interruptions in your ability to process redemptions and subscriptions?

The expected time is about three months due to the yield accrual on these tokens. However, there is no maximum time as the bonds will rebase weekly and can be held perpetually—users who have held our bonds since their first release in November 2023. We have not had any issues processing redemptions or subscriptions.

  1. Provide a description of the subscription and redemption process. Include a diagram of the flow of funds, including each party involved.

Minting/Purchasing

Divesting

Flow of Funds

  1. Have any liquidity vehicles been established to enhance redemption and subscription efficiency? If so, describe how they work.

Yes we currently provide about 1MM on both the buy/sell side to enhance purchase and redemption.

16.With what product can subscriptions and redemptions be made? (i.e., fiat, Dai, USDC, etc.)

USDC

  1. What are your future development plans for the product?

We intend to integrate the product onto more blockchains and exchanges. Additionally, create other products with different sovereign treasury instruments.

IV. Legal Structure

  1. Explain the legal structure of the product and the jurisdictions in which it operates.

We are both operated and regulated in Mexico. We are only excluded from working with a few localities generally found on terrorist watch lists and the US.

  1. What regulatory bodies oversee the product?

CNBV Comisión Nacional Bancaria y Valores, who is responsible for regulating Mexican financial institutions. Our products and services are in compliance with corporate laws and Mexican Regulations:

  • Securities Market Law, Federal Consumer Protection Law, Personal Data Protection Law, Commerce Code, Federal Civil Code, Civil Procedures Code, Credit Institutions Law, and the Law to Regulate Financial Technology Solutions.

  • Additional Authorities: the Ministry of Economy, the Industrial Property Institute, and brokerage houses where assets are purchased

  1. What licenses, permits, certificates, authorizations, registrations, concessions, approvals, exemptions does your product or company hold?

We are a fully regulated company and are authorized to tokenize and sell our Stablebonds. We stay up to date on all certifications and registrations to meet CNBV requirements in Mexico. Privacy Document.

  1. How is bankruptcy remoteness established for assets of this product? Does the issuer have more than one product? Please provide separately any related legal opinions or supplementary documents regarding bankruptcy remoteness.

Mexico’s regulatory framework includes structural mechanisms designed to minimize the risk of insolvency for legal entities. These mechanisms enhance the effectiveness of provisions that prevent creditors and investors from initiating insolvency proceedings against the legal entity or seizing its assets, including those of its compartments, estates, or sub-funds. Additionally we are fully transparent as to the accounting, brokerage and custody of customers funds with weekly third party attestations.

  1. What rights do token holders have?

The only restriction for tokenholders is payout time. Users can divest their funds at any time, but will not be paid until the next issuance (weekly.) Once a person holds our tokens, they are the complete custodian, they can stake trade, or sell.

  1. Are there any pending or threatened legal proceedings or investigations against the company or any of its officers?

No

  1. Describe any conflicts of interest the company or product may have with its officers or MakerDAO.

None

  1. Explain the potential tax implications associated with the product

Like any other investment, it is the responsibility of the user to claim and pay taxes associated with the assets they purchase.

V. Performance, Reporting, and Technical

  1. Provide historical performance relative to the most relevant benchmark and explanations for any deviations from the benchmark

The benchmark for our US treasury bonds is the historical interest rate. There has not been any deviation from this benchmark as we are offering 5% APY. Return will remain consistent with the rate offered minus the .25% fee.

  1. Describe the frequency, content, and process for performance and portfolio transparency reports. Who provides these?

We continuously monitor our performances by tracking the total value tokens circulating.

Upon each new issuance, attestation reports are uploaded from our legal partners, who generate, sign, and attest these documents, verifying that we hold the reserves we claim.

  1. Describe the accounting and auditing processes for the portfolio and product

We have independent accountants and legal entities audit our underlying asset reserves. Each week, we publish an attestation report on our website. This report is uploaded by our legal partner, Legal Paradox, verifies our reserves and signs a legal document confirming we hold the assets we claim.

  1. Describe the technical implementation of your product

We have completely automated our tokenization process. Bond offerings are created with specific mints and data that emulate the bond mechanics. Stablebond mechanics are implemented via on-chain smart contracts. Upon tokenization, there is initial funding that permits users to purchase bond-specific tokens. Following the funding period, Stablebonds accrue interest in the holders’ wallet. Read more about implementation in our neon paper.

  1. What audits have been performed on the smart contracts involved with your product, by whom, and when?

2024 Ottersec

VI. MakerDAO Ecosystem

  1. Describe any previous relationship with MakerDAO and familiarity working with DAOs

We have no previous experience with MakerDAO

  1. Beyond yield, how might your product benefit the SparkDAO and/or MakerDAO ecosystem?

We differentiate ourselves with our ability to tap into the liquidity of the Mexican bond market to enable large volumes of buy/sell liquidity during market hours. New bonds are purchased and minted during market hours, giving us the flexibility to purchase or redeem as much or little as needed. Additionally the added decentralization of an alternative regulatory environment than alternative tokenized products.

  1. Does the product have integrations with any other platforms?

Brale, Jupiter, Phantom

  1. Do you offer or plan to offer other products that could be appropriate for Spark or other SubDAOs?

We offer US, Mexican Cetes European and Brazilian Treasuries.

item.title: Tokenization Grand Prix Application – Franklin Templeton Digital Assets (BENJI)
item.dc:creator: rgolubov
item.description:
I. Product Summary

1. Project name: Franklin Templeton Digital Assets
2. Product name: Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund (the “Fund”)
3. Product type / underlying asset: Tokenized, U.S. registered U.S. Government money market fund
4. Issuer jurisdiction: United States
5. Product website: Fund information here: Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund - FOBXX (franklintempleton.com). More information about FT Digital Assets Technology here: Digital Assets Technology | Alternatives by FT and FT Digital Assets Technical
6. Primary contact name, title, and method of contact: Ric Golubov – VP, Business Development. Please contact via email: ric.golubov@franklintempleton.com

II. Company Details

1. Company description

Franklin Resources, Inc. is the holding company for various subsidiaries that form the global investment management organization known as Franklin Templeton. Today, Franklin Resources, Inc. is one of the largest publicly traded investment management companies in the world, with offices in over 30 countries. The company is listed on the New York Stock Exchange under the ticker BEN and is a constituent of the S&P 500 Index.

With more than 75 years of active management experience, Franklin Templeton offers investment solutions to help clients achieve better outcomes. Our independent specialist investment managers (SIMs) provide clients with deep expertise and boutique specialization across asset classes, investment styles, and geographies. Furthermore, our SIMs are backed by a global infrastructure with at-scale capabilities in research, data analytics, and servicing—this combination of independent, entrepreneurial SIMs and global strength makes Franklin Templeton uniquely agile and allows us to offer 200+ investment strategies across a full range of vehicles.

As of August 31, 2024 Franklin Templeton managed total assets of US$1.68 trillion.

Investors in the Fund work directly with Franklin Templeton Digital Assets. Founded in 2018, Franklin Templeton Digital Assets believes that blockchain technology has the ability to create efficiencies across a variety of business processes, which is why we are building our own blockchain-based technology solutions to support these assets in the investment management space. Our team built a full service proprietary blockchain-based technology stack to support a blockchain-enabled money fund, known as the Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund, which includes a digital transfer agent platform, digital asset management system, and digital wallet infrastructure. The Fund’s transfer agent maintains the official record of share ownership via a proprietary blockchain-integrated system that utilizes public blockchains as the source of truth for recording transactional activity, known as the Benji platform. Investors can gain exposure to the Fund through BENJI Tokens, which are minted natively on-chain. One BENJI Token is equivalent to one share of the Fund.

In addition, Franklin Templeton Digital Assets is committed to investing in the early stages of the digital assets market and in tokens that are listed on digital asset exchanges. We also have operated as a node validator since 2019, helping to support the security and infrastructure of over ten public blockchain networks.

2. Key personnel biographies

The two portfolio managers of this Fund are Shawn Lyons and Johnson Ng, with 28 and 26 years of service, respectively.

Shawn Lyons, Senior Vice President and Portfolio Manager for Franklin Templeton Fixed Income – Corporate Credit, is responsible for managing Franklin Templeton’s taxable money funds and Franklin Managed Income Fund. Shawn has over 28 years of experience in the financial services industry. Prior to his current role, Shawn was a Portfolio Manager and Research Analyst for Franklin Templeton Fixed Income - Money Markets. Shawn joined Franklin Templeton in 1996 as a Futures Associate. Shawn holds a Bachelor of Arts in economics from University of California, Berkeley. He is a Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA) charterholder and a member of the CFA Society of San Francisco and the CFA Institute.

Johnson Ng, Vice President and Portfolio Manager for Franklin Templeton Fixed Income – Corporate Credit, is responsible for managing Franklin money market portfolios and participating in short-term investing. His areas cover all taxable money funds and the cash portion of the taxable non-money funds. Johnson has over 26 years of prior experience in the financial services industry. Prior to his current role, Johnson was a Futures Associate for Franklin Templeton. He joined Franklin Templeton in 1997 as a broker dealer representative. Johnson holds a Bachelor of Arts in international relations from University of California at Davis. He is a Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA) charterholder, and a member of the CFA Society of San Francisco and the CFA Institute.

Franklin Templeton Digital Assets manages the proprietary blockchain-enabled technology to support the BENJI Token, known as the Benji platform.

Roger Bayston, Executive Vice President and Head of Digital Assets, leads digital asset efforts at Franklin Templeton. His team is responsible for creating new generations of products and services focused on the rapidly expanding opportunities within digital assets and their supporting infrastructure. This includes services dedicated to mature cryptocurrency powered blockchain networks and newer incubator projects committed to companies in the distributed ledger space. Roger’s team also builds infrastructure that bridges traditional financial market products and services into the digital asset ecosystem. Roger has over 38 years of experience in the financial services industry. He is a member of the Firm’s Management Committee and currently serves on the Board for Fiduciary Trust Company, a wealth management subsidiary of Franklin Templeton. Roger joined Franklin Templeton in 1991 as a Research Analyst and has been a business leader for Franklin Templeton Fixed Income for many years. Roger holds a Bachelor of Science from University of Virginia and an MBA from University of California at Los Angeles. Prior to getting his MBA he was previously with Bankers Trust Company. He is a Chartered Financial Analyst (CFA) charterholder.

Mike Muir, Senior Vice President and Head of Digital Assets Technology, manages the team who is responsible for the Firm’s application development across the digital asset landscape. Mike has over 18 years of experience in the financial services industry. Prior to his current role, Mike was responsible for enterprise software systems addressing trade order and execution management, portfolio construction and monitoring, performance attribution and risk management, and ETFs. He also has software development experience in client reporting, web presence, data warehousing, and anti-money laundering systems. Mike joined Franklin Templeton in 2006 as a Senior Technical Consultant. Mike has subject matter expertise in general programming concepts, data structures, concurrency and multi-threading, software configuration management, and performance profiling across a wide variety of programming languages and runtimes. In his current role, Mike studies first and second order blockchain protocols and application implementations, contributing to Franklin Templeton’s strategies across digital assets of all varieties.

3. Team size

Franklin Templeton Fixed Income, the investment team who manages the Fund’s portfolio, manages US$205 billion as of June 30, 2024 across a comprehensive, diverse range of single- and multi-sector investment strategies. The group is made up of 200+ investment professionals based in London, New York, San Mateo, and Singapore, along with regional Fixed Income teams in Australia, Canada, India, Malaysia, Mexico, U.A.E., and Poland. Team members have an average of 19 years of investment experience. Based on size, global presence and depth of expertise, and leveraging our comprehensive understanding of the interaction of the global economic environment and world bond markets, Franklin Templeton is strategically positioned to identify alpha opportunities across all major market sectors.

Franklin Templeton Digital Assets, the team who built the proprietary technology stack to support the BENJI Token, has over 50 people dedicated across our key initiatives: Digital Assets Technology, Digital Assets Investment Strategies and Node Operations. The team bridges traditional investment expertise with technology development knowledge specifically with blockchain and digital assets. Our team strives to allow access to this nascent asset class through research-driven investment portfolios and through traditional financial products that leverage the efficiencies of blockchain technology, like the BENJI Token. Our global team is engaged in every stage of this new market, positioning us as a competitive provider of digital assets investment strategies and technology solutions.

4. Years in operation

The Fund was launched on April 6, 2021. Franklin Templeton Digital Assets has been engaged in research and technical development within the digital asset ecosystem since 2018, developing technology platforms and strategy differentiation to help clients achieve their investment goals in this new asset class, all while supporting and investing in digital asset networks.

III. Product Information

1. Describe the product

Under this proposal, SparkDAO (Decentralized Autonomous Organization) would be invested in the Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund, which is the world’s first U.S. registered money market mutual fund offered and issued on blockchain in tokenized form. An investment in the BENJI Token, which is a digital asset security that represents one share of the Fund, can help diversify SparkDAO’s DAI reserves and/or treasury into a steady, income-generating asset that seeks to provide capital preservation, and its liquidity preservation characteristics present a unique opportunity for SparkDAO’s reserves.

While minor, many of the largest stablecoins have faced price volatility in the peg of their stablecoin. Similar to the objective of stablecoins, the Fund seeks to maintain a stable $1.00 share price (NAV). The Fund has maintained this NAV since inception, having provided price stability, and is also required by law to provide quarterly public disclosure of all holdings. The Fund’s 7-day current yield is 5.12% as of August 31, 2024, with a 20 basis point net expense ratio. Fund shares are offered without sales charge. The Fund is registered as an investment company under the Investment Company Act of 1940 and invests 99.5% of its total assets in Government securities, cash and repurchase agreements collateralized fully by Government securities or cash.

The BENJI Token is designed to provide transparency by using blockchain technology to process transactions and record share ownership. The Fund’s transfer agent maintains the official record of share ownership via a proprietary blockchain-integrated system that utilizes public blockchains as the source of truth for recording transactional activity, known as the Benji platform. It’s important to note that there is no personally identifiable information stored on the blockchain, only transaction-level data. Because the Benji platform records transactions and Fund ownership via public blockchains, and because this on-chain record serves as the true system of record with no shadow record keeping behind the scenes, SparkDAO would have real-time transparency and assurance that their assets are in good stead. SparkDAO can interact with their account at any time using our Benji Institutional Web Portal and provide a look through to their holdings using their preferred block explorer, such as Etherscan for Ethereum.

Please see below for a preview of our Institutional Web Portal supporting the BENJI Token.


Please see below for previews of the modal interface for ZeroHash on Benji Institutional.


While BENJI Token subscriptions and redemptions are typically done in fiat, namely USD, investors in the BENJI Token are not required to utilize a bank account. Zero Hash conversion services, which are available on the Benji platform, allow investors to convert US Dollar Coins (USDC) to USD, which in turn is transferred to their Franklin Templeton account and used to seamlessly purchase BENJI Tokens. Investors in the Fund may also use Zero Hash services to convert USD proceeds from the sale of BENJI Tokens to USDC. These conversions do not require USDC being on the same network as BENJI Tokens.

Ensuring the safety and stability of treasury and reserve funds is of the utmost importance and, as a result, many invest in stablecoins to try to preserve capital. Stablecoin providers invest the underlying assets across many different investment types to generate return but rarely pass that return to holders of the stablecoin. In the case of the BENJI Token, we believe that SparkDAO’s reserves and/or treasury can not only receive the benefit of capital preservation but can also earn any income generated from the Fund’s holdings through an asset that lives natively on-chain. Any income generated by investing in the BENJI Token can provide additional capital to aid in the development of new products, technology, or other initiatives deemed important to SparkDAO.

We would like to advocate for SparkDAO to liquidate a portion of its DAI reserves and/or treasury to invest in the BENJI Token. Please refer to Appendix 1 - Say Hello to Benji for more information on the BENJI Token and process of investing.

2. Describe the underlying asset

The Fund intends to be a “Government money market fund,” as such term is defined in or interpreted under Rule 2a-7 under the Investment Company Act of 1940 (1940 Act). The Fund invests at least 99.5% of its assets in Government securities, cash and repurchase agreements collateralized fully by Government securities or cash.

The Fund invests in:

  • U.S. government securities, which may include fixed, floating and variable rate securities.
  • Repurchase agreements which are agreements by the Fund to buy Government securities and then to sell the securities back on an agreed upon date (generally, less than seven days) at a higher price, which reflects prevailing short-term interest rates.

The Fund’s portfolio managers seek to build a diversified portfolio of Government securities. Government securities include those issued by government agencies or instrumentalities, such as the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fannie Mae), Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation (Freddie Mac), Federal Home Loan Banks and Federal Farm Credit Banks, whose securities are neither issued nor guaranteed by the U.S. Government.

The portfolio managers make the final security selection decisions, consistent with desired overall risk positioning, and based on relative pricing and trading liquidity. Throughout the portfolio construction process, dedicated risk analysts collaborate with the portfolio managers to identify the level and sources of risk and help determine optimal position sizing.

The Fund only buys securities that the investment manager determines present minimal credit risks. The Fund maintains a dollar-weighted average portfolio maturity of 60 calendar days or less, maintains a dollar-weighted average life for its portfolio of 120 calendar days or less, and only buys securities that mature or are deemed to mature in 397 calendar days or less. As of August 31, 2024, the Fund’s weighted average maturity was 16 days, and 27 days as of June 30, 2024.

The Fund uses the amortized cost method of valuation to seek to maintain a stable $1.00 share price and does not currently intend to impose liquidity fees or redemption gates on Fund redemptions.

An Institutional Web Portal is available for institutional investors and other investors that require a multi-user interface for Fund subscriptions and redemptions.

3. How is yield transferred to the tokenholder (i.e., via rebasing, distributions, price accrual, etc.) and how often?

Income received from the Fund are paid daily when its net asset value (NAV) is calculated, which is based on NYSE business days. Your account (via the Institutional Web Portal) begins to receive dividends on the day after the Fund receives your investment, provided the investment is received by the Fund on any business day in good order prior to 1 p.m. Pacific time or the regularly scheduled close of the NYSE, whichever is earlier. Investments received after that time will normally begin to earn dividends on the following business day. Dividends from net investment income are normally declared and distributed daily; these dividends may be reinvested or paid daily to shareholders directly to their account in the form of additional BENJI tokens.

4. What is the jurisdiction of the issuer and key entities?

Franklin Resources, Inc. is the holding company for various subsidiaries that form the global investment management organization known as Franklin Templeton. Today, Franklin Resources, Inc. is one of the largest publicly traded investment management companies in the world, offering investment products and services in over 150 countries with offices in more than 80 cities and more than 9,000 global staff, including 1,500+ investment professionals.

Franklin Templeton Trust (Trust) is registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940 (1940 Act) as an open-end management investment company, consisting of one series – the Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund. The Fund intends to be a “Government money market fund,” as such term is defined in or interpreted under Rule 2a-7 under the Investment Company Act of 1940 (1940 Act) and is registered with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). For more information, please contact our team or visit the Fund’s Prospectus: Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund - FOBXX (franklintempleton.com).

5. What is the asset eligibility criteria and/or concentration limitations for the portfolio as defined by the underlying documents?

As previously mentioned, the Fund invests at least 99.5% of its total assets in Government securities, cash and repurchase agreements collateralized fully by Government securities or cash.

6. Are any hedging or derivatives permitted in the underlying portfolio?

No, the Fund does not use any hedging or derivative products.

7. Provide a list of all counterparties and service providers used by your product (i.e., custodians, trustees, reporting agents, exchange agents, banks, etc). Provide flow-charts or diagrams for all related entities and counterparties, if available.

The Fund’s key counterparties and service providers are as follows:

  • Distribution and underwriting: The Fund continuously offers its shares through Franklin Distributors, LLC. Franklin Distributors, LLC also acts as the principal underwriter in the continuous public offering of the Fund’s shares.
  • Investment manager and services provided: The Fund’s investment manager is Franklin Advisers, Inc. The investment manager is a wholly owned subsidiary of Franklin Resources, Inc., a publicly owned company engaged in the financial services industry through its subsidiaries.
  • Administrator and services provided: Franklin Templeton Services, LLC (FT Services) has an agreement with the investment manager to provide certain administrative services and facilities for the Fund. FT Services is an indirect, wholly owned subsidiary of Franklin Resources, Inc. and is an affiliate of the Fund’s investment manager and principal underwriter. The administrative services FT Services provides include preparing and maintaining books, records, and tax and financial reports, and monitoring compliance with regulatory requirements.
  • Shareholder servicing and transfer agent: Franklin Templeton Investor Services, LLC (Investor Services) is the Fund’s shareholder servicing agent and acts as the Fund’s transfer agent and dividend-paying agent. Investor Services receives a fee for servicing Fund shareholder accounts. The Fund also will reimburse Investor Services for certain out-of-pocket expenses necessarily incurred in servicing the shareholder accounts in accordance with the terms of its servicing contract with the Fund.
  • Sub-administrator: JPMorgan Chase Bank, N.A. (JPMorgan) has an agreement with FT Services to provide certain sub-administrative services for the Fund. The administrative services provided by JPMorgan include, but are not limited to, certain fund accounting, financial reporting, tax, corporate governance and compliance and legal administration services.
  • Custodian: JPMorgan Chase Bank, at its principal office at 270 Park Avenue, New York, NY 10017-2070, and at the offices of its branches and agencies throughout the world, acts as custodian of the Fund’s assets.
  • Independent Registered Public Accounting Firm: PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, 405 Howard Street, Suite 600, San Francisco, CA 94105, is the Fund’s independent registered public accounting firm. The independent registered public accounting firm audits the financial statements included in the Fund’s Annual Report to shareholders.

Institutional investors may open a new account by using our Institutional Web Portal. Please see the graphic below for our flow of funds process from fiat, namely USD, via Fed Wire for purchases; for redemptions, please see the same graphic. Please note, however, that this process does not cover subscriptions and redemptions via USDC through our partnership with Zero Hash. We would be happy to walk SparkDAO through that process, if needed.

In the subscription and liquidation of shares of the Fund, Franklin Templeton utilizes JP.Morgan Chase Bank as a third party counterparty for the Fed Wire process.

8. What is the AUM of the product? Provide a breakdown by blockchain

As of June 30, 2024, the AUM for the Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund was US$401.98 million, and US$427.96 million as of August 31, 2024. As of August 31, 2024, $425.82 million of this AUM is on the Stellar, and $2.14 million on Polygon, Arbitrum, Avalanche. As of September 4, 2024, we’re also accepting subscriptions for Ethereum mainnet.

9. What are the standard fees (i.e., subscription, redemption, management, etc.)?

The Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund’s total annual fund operating expenses after fee waiver and/or expense reimbursement is 0.20% (net expense ratio) as the investment manager has contractually agreed to waive or assume certain fees and expenses until July 31, 2025. The Fund’s gross expense ratio is 0.26%. Fund shares are offered without a sales charge. For clarification on fees, please contact our team.

Please see below table for a summary of the fees and expenses that you may pay if you buy and hold shared of the Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund:

10. Other than the fees described above, can other expenses be paid from the proceeds of the product/assets?

No, please see the answer to question 9 above.

11. How is your product permissioned? (e.g., primary users, secondary users)

Users of the Benji platform are run through typical KYC/AML verification and are whitelisted inside the contract (using ERC-20 roles).

12. What is the monthly transaction volume for the product?

Over the last 12 months, the Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund has done over 1900 transactions. This does not include daily dividend reinvestments. BENJI tokens are not traded on a secondary market. The Fund is organized as an open-end mutual fund so investors can generally purchase or redeem BENJI Tokens directly from the Fund on days that the at the New York Stock Exchange is open for trading.

13. What is the expected and maximum time for users to subscribe to and redeem from your product? Have you had any interruptions in your ability to process redemptions and subscriptions?

Expected and maximum time for users to subscribe to and redeem from the Fund depends on the time of the subscription or redemption. If we receive your request in proper form prior to 1 p.m. Pacific time, or the regularly scheduled close of the New York Stock Exchange, whichever is earlier, proceeds sent by ACH generally will be available within two to three business days, however, in most cases, we are able to make the proceeds available same day. Institutional Fed Wires must be received prior to 3 p.m. Pacific time in order to receive same day trade date. We have not had any interruptions in our ability to process redemptions and subscriptions to date.

14. Provide a description of the subscription and redemption process. Include a diagram of the flow of funds, including each party involved.

Subscriptions and redemptions for the Fund are typically done in fiat via Fed Wire for institutional investors, however, we also provide the ability to convert USDC to BENJI Tokens (or BENJI Tokens to USDC) through an agreement we have with Zero Hash. As mentioned in the question above, all Fund transactions must be conducted via the Institutional Web Portal.

You can redeem your shares at any time through the Institutional Web Portal, although redemptions of Fund shares will only be processed during normal business hours on business days (NYSE business days). Institutional investors making redemptions via the Institutional Web Portal will use a submitter/approver process to authorize transactions.

Redemption proceeds will be sent by electronic funds transfer (Fed Wire) from your Institutional Web Portal account to your bank account within seven days after we receive your request in proper form.

Before requesting to have redemption proceeds sent to a bank account, please make sure we have your current bank account information on file.

If the bank account was added or changed within the last 15 days, you may be required to provide written instructions signed by all Fund account owners, with a signature guarantee for each Fund account owner.

If we receive your request in proper form prior to 1 p.m. Pacific time, or the regularly scheduled close of the New York Stock Exchange, whichever is earlier, proceeds sent by ACH generally will be available within two to three business days, however, in most cases, we are able to make the proceeds available same day.

For a diagram of the flow of funds, please see the graphic in question 7 above.

15. Have any liquidity vehicles been established to enhance redemption and subscription efficiency? If so, describe how they work.

No, however, the investment manager may also hold cash when securities meeting the Fund’s investment criteria are unavailable or to maintain liquidity. The Fund only buys securities that at the time of acquisition are “eligible securities,” as defined by applicable regulation (e.g., government securities, securities issued by a money market fund, and securities that the investment manager determines present minimal credit risks). As previously mentioned, the Fund maintains a dollar-weighted average portfolio maturity of 60 calendar days or less, maintains a dollar-weighted average life for its portfolio of 120 calendar days or less, and only buys securities that mature or are deemed to mature in 397 calendar days or less (or securities otherwise permitted to be purchased because of maturity shortening provisions under applicable regulation).

16. With what product can subscriptions and redemptions be made? (i.e., fiat, Dai, USDC, etc.)

While BENJI Token subscriptions and redemptions are typically done in fiat, namely USD, investors in the BENJI Token are not required to utilize a bank account. Zero Hash conversion services allow investors to convert USDC to USD, which in turn is transferred to their Franklin Templeton account and used to seamlessly purchase BENJI Tokens. Investors in the Fund may also use Zero Hash services to convert USD proceeds from the sale of BENJI Tokens to USDC.

17. What are your future development plans for the product?

We are working on a number of enhancements that bring new functionality to money market funds not seen before, including but not limited to:

  • Support for subscribing/redeeming using a wider variety of tokens beyond USDC
  • Self-custody and web3 wallet interfaces
  • A general purpose GraphQL API
  • Expansion to issue BENJI on even more blockchain networks
  • Further enhancements to peer-to-peer transferability
  • Availability through third party distributors/exchanges

These features are naturally subject to regulations and regulatory interpretations. If you would like to learn more about these development efforts, we would be happy to offer discussion with our engineering team members.

IV. Legal Structure

1. Explain the legal structure of the product and the jurisdictions in which it operates

As mentioned above in question 4 under the “Product Information” section, Franklin Templeton Trust (Trust) is registered under the Investment Company Act of 1940 (1940 Act) as an open-end management investment company, consisting of one series – the Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund. The Fund intends to be a “Government money market fund,” as such term is defined in or interpreted under Rule 2a-7 under the Investment Company Act of 1940 (1940 Act) and is registered with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC). For more information, please contact our team or visit the Fund’s Prospectus: Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund - FOBXX (franklintempleton.com).

2. What regulatory bodies oversee the product?

Please see the answer to question 1 above.

3. What licenses, permits, certificates, authorizations, registrations, concessions, approvals, exemptions does your product or company hold?

Please see the answer to question 1 above.

4. How is bankruptcy remoteness established for assets of this product? Does the issuer have more than one product? Please provide separately any related legal opinions or supplementary documents regarding bankruptcy remoteness

The Fund’s assets are maintained by a qualified custodian and are separate from holdings of the Fund’s investment manager or its affiliates. Because the Fund’s investment manager is prohibited from comingling Fund assets with assets of the investment manager or its affiliates, a bankruptcy by the investment manager or an affiliate would not subject Fund assets to risk of creditors in any bankruptcy proceedings. As previously mentioned, it is also important to note that the Fund intends to be a “government money market fund” as such term is defined in or interpreted under Rule 2a-7 under the Investment Company Act of 1940 (1940 Act). The Fund invests at least 99.5% of its total assets in Government securities, cash and repurchase agreements collateralized fully by Government securities or cash.

Yes, the issuer has more than one product. The Fund’s investment manager is Franklin Advisers, Inc. The investment manager is a wholly owned subsidiary of Franklin Resources, Inc., a publicly owned company engaged in the financial services industry through its subsidiaries. Franklin Resources, Inc. is the holding company for various subsidiaries that form the global investment management organization known as Franklin Templeton. With more than 75 years of active management experience, Franklin Templeton offers investment solutions to help clients achieve better outcomes. Our independent specialist investment managers (SIMs) provide clients with deep expertise and boutique specialization across asset classes, investment styles, and geographies. Furthermore, as we mentioned previously, our SIMs are backed by a global infrastructure with at-scale capabilities in research, data analytics, and servicing—this combination of independent, entrepreneurial SIMs and global strength makes Franklin Templeton uniquely agile and allows us to offer 200+ investment strategies across a full range of vehicles.

The Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund is managed by Franklin Templeton’s Fixed Income portfolio management team.

5. What rights do token holders have?

The Fund is a series of Franklin Templeton Trust, which is an open-end investment company under the Investment Company Act of 1940 Act (the “1940”), which confers certain rights to all shareholders, including, among other rights, the right to: (i) vote for the board of trustees; (ii) approve the Fund’s investment management agreement; and (iii) vote on other Fund-specific matters.

6. Are there any pending or threatened legal proceedings or investigations against the company or any of its officers?

To the best of our knowledge, there are no pending or threatened legal proceedings or investigations against the Fund or its officers.

During the year ended June 30, 2024, neither Franklin Advisers, Inc. (FAV) nor, to the best of its knowledge, its individual advisory affiliates was named as a respondent in any regulatory investment-related proceedings brought by any U.S. federal or state regulatory agency, foreign financial regulatory authority, or self-regulatory organization. Further, in connection with investigations by multiple state attorneys general (“AGs”) concerning Environmental Social and Governance-related investment activities of asset managers in the industry, in 2023, FAV received two Civil Investigative Demands (“CIDs”) issued by AGs of the State of Louisiana and the Commonwealth of Kentucky. We submitted responses to the CIDs in July and August 2023. On February 6, 2024, the Office of the Louisiana AG confirmed that FAV has complied with the CID and that the CID is no longer outstanding. As of the quarter ended June 30, 2024, we have received no further requests for documents or information under the CID from the Office of the Kentucky AG. Investment-related proceedings, findings or orders resulting from the investigations, if any, will be reported, to the extent required and permitted by law, on FAV’s Form ADV filed with the SEC.

For a summary of investment-related proceedings, findings or orders brought or issued by any such regulatory entity against FAV and/or certain of its advisory affiliates in the past 10 years ended June 30, 2024, as well as certain other regulatory matters, please see Appendix 2 – Franklin Advisers, Inc. Regulatory Summary . In addition, from time to time, FAV and its advisory affiliates receive subpoenas and inquiries, including requests for documents or information, from governmental authorities or regulatory bodies and also are the subject of governmental or regulatory examinations or investigations. Investment-related proceedings, findings or orders resulting from such subpoenas, inquiries, examinations, or investigations, if any, will be reported, to the extent required and permitted by law, on FAV’s Form ADV filed with the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC).

For a summary of material, investment-management-related private litigation in which FAV and/or certain of its advisory affiliates were named as defendants at any point in the past five years ended June 30, 2024, please see Appendix 3 – Franklin Advisers, Inc. 5-Year Litigation Summary. In addition, FAV and its advisory affiliates are from time to time named in litigation in the ordinary course of business, including currently. To the extent any such litigation is currently pending, as of the date of this response, none is reasonably expected to have a material adverse effect on FAV’s financial condition or ability to provide investment management services. (Italicized terms are as defined on SEC’s Form ADV.)

7. Describe any conflicts of interest the company or product may have with its officers or MakerDAO

As of September 2024, we do not believe that Franklin Templeton or the Fund has any conflicts of interest with MakerDAO.

Franklin Templeton has a corporate policy aimed to mitigate conflicts of interest. Franklin Templeton’s policy is to take all reasonable steps to maintain and operate effective organizational and administrative controls to identify and manage relevant conflicts that may occur between Franklin Templeton and its clients or between multiple clients.

The following list provides a summary of the main conflicts we have identified and the controls in place to manage such conflicts within the Franklin Templeton group.

  • Franklin Templeton Seed Money versus Shareholders’ Investment. As part of normal business practice, Franklin Templeton will invest money, initially, at the launch of a fund in order to diversify and attract clients. The policy is that an investment by Franklin Templeton is treated in a manner that is believed to not conflict with the interests of any client.

  • Fairness of Trading Allocation and Order Priority among Clients**.** Franklin Templeton has trading aggregation, allocation, and best execution policies and procedures that are designed to ensure that all trades are treated in an equitable and fiduciary manner relative to investment objectives. Where there is insufficient liquidity, the allocation policy automatically attributes liquidity proportionately across all client orders. The aggregation and allocation procedures are subject to a regular review.

  • Interfund Trading and Franklin Templeton Funds Purchasing Franklin Templeton Funds. At times, Franklin Templeton may match internal orders of sales and purchases of portfolio securities. This is known as crosses or Interfunds. Some Franklin Templeton funds can also trade units in other Franklin Templeton funds. This process is dealt with in the existing trading system and procedures. The trade is executed at market price with no commissions or spread taken by Franklin Templeton. This activity is regularly reviewed with the goal of ensuring that clients are treated fairly.

  • Research Material and Client Commissions. Franklin Templeton (FT) proprietary research material is not offered to the general public for sale. FT may enter into Client Commission Arrangements (CCAs), whereby FT directs trades to a broker-dealer with the instruction that the executing broker segregate commission in excess of execution costs in a pool which may be used to compensate brokers and other third parties that provide research services or products to FT. FT has established policies and standards that include ongoing monitoring, oversight, and audit controls.

  • The Use of Sensitive Data and Non-Public Information. Franklin Templeton has a number of policies and procedures in place that place restrictions on staff use of confidential or non-public information. There are formal reporting and approval procedures to release such information to satisfy Franklin Templeton’s fiduciary obligations to clients and shareholders. These policies and procedures are regularly reviewed.

  • Information Barrier among Investment Advisors and Broker-Dealer Relationships. With the goal of ensuring that sensitive decision information cannot be used to the disadvantage of another fund and that confidential information is not shared inappropriately, Franklin Templeton has Information Barrier Compliance Policy and Procedures in place that separate the physical and logistical investment information between different advisor groups.

  • Code of Ethics. All Franklin Templeton personnel are bound by a Code of Ethics and Business Conduct which requires staff to conduct themselves with ethics and integrity and to avoid a conflict, particularly where their personal interests (including family members) could interfere with the interests of the firm and/or the client. In addition, Franklin Templeton has a Personal Investments and Insider Trading Policy that requires pre-clearance of personal transactions, including those of the immediate family of staff members who have access to non-public information regarding securities transactions, securities recommendations, or portfolio holding of FT funds or client accounts. Personal transactions of such staff members are regularly monitored, and prescribed sanctions are issued in the event of a breach.

  • Equitable and Fair Treatment among Clients. At the heart of Franklin Templeton procedures is the requirement to treat clients fairly and equitably in line with the firm’s fiduciary obligations and investment objectives. This includes, but is not limited to, activity such as the allocation of fees and expenses, redemption in kind, and the lending of securities of a fund. Franklin Templeton procedures are regularly reviewed.

  • Investment in Client Securities. At times, Franklin Templeton funds or investors will invest in the securities of a company for which Franklin Templeton serves as investment manager. Such investment decisions made by Franklin Templeton to invest in client securities are always guided by what is in the best interest of the relevant fund, account, or its investors. Investment decisions are regularly reviewed.

  • Gifts and Entertainment. Franklin Templeton has adopted strict guidelines regarding what gifts and business entertainment are acceptable. The policy is part of our Code of Ethics, any violation of which may result in disciplinary action up to and including termination.

  • Side-by-Side Management. Franklin Templeton has implemented “Policies and Procedures for Side-By-Side Management of Registered Investment Companies and Investment Accounts” designed to address potential conflicts of interest that may arise when a portfolio manager or different portfolio managers within a single investment adviser or within a single investment group manage both U.S.-registered funds and other investment accounts or pooled vehicles for other advisory clients.

8. Explain the potential tax implications associated with the product

Fund distributions, which will be automatically reinvested in additional shares, are generally taxable to you as ordinary income, capital gains or some combination of both. Investment company dividends paid to you from interest earned on certain U.S. government securities may be exempt from state and local taxation, subject in some states to minimum investment or reporting requirements that must be met by the Fund.

Dividend income: Income dividends are generally subject to tax at ordinary rates. Because the Fund invests primarily in debt securities, it is expected that none of the Fund’s income dividends will be qualified dividends subject to reduced rates of taxation to individuals. A return-of-capital distribution is generally not taxable but will reduce the cost basis of your shares, and will result in a higher capital gain or a lower capital loss when you later sell your shares.

Capital gains: Fund distributions of short-term capital gains are also subject to tax at ordinary rates. Because the Fund is a money market fund, it does not expect to realize and distribute any long-term capital gains on its investments.

Sales of Fund shares: Because the Fund seeks to maintain a $1.00 per share NAV, sales of its shares will not generally result in a taxable capital gain or loss for federal or state income tax purposes.

Medicare tax: An additional 3.8% Medicare tax is imposed on certain net investment income (including ordinary dividends and capital gain distributions received from the Fund and net gains from redemptions or other taxable dispositions of Fund shares) of U.S. individuals, estates and trusts to the extent that such person’s “modified adjusted gross income” (in the case of an individual) or “adjusted gross income” (in the case of an estate or trust) exceeds a threshold amount. Any liability for this additional Medicare tax is reported on, and paid with, your federal income tax return.

Backup withholding: A shareholder may be subject to backup withholding on any distributions of income and capital gains if the shareholder has provided either an incorrect tax identification number or no number at all, is subject to backup withholding by the IRS for failure to properly report payments of interest or dividends, has failed to certify that the shareholder is not subject to backup withholding, or has not certified that the shareholder is a U.S. person (including a U.S. resident alien). The backup withholding rate is currently 24%. State backup withholding may also apply.

State and local taxes: Distributions of ordinary income and capital gains, if any are generally subject to state and local taxes. However, distributions of ordinary income paid to individual shareholders from interest earned by the Fund on certain U.S. Government obligations may be exempt from state and local income taxation depending on the state. Shareholders should contact their tax advisors with respect to the state and local income tax consequences of investing in the Fund, including whether Fund dividends derived from interest on U.S. government obligations held by the Fund qualify for tax free treatment.

Non-U.S. investors: Non-U.S. investors may be subject to U.S. withholding tax at 30% or a lower treaty rate on Fund dividends of ordinary income. Non-U.S. investors may be subject to U.S. estate tax on the value of their shares. They are subject to special U.S. tax certification requirements to avoid backup withholding, claim any exemptions from withholding and claim any treaty benefits. Exemptions from U.S. withholding tax are generally provided for capital gains realized on the sale of Fund shares, capital gain dividends paid by the Fund from net long-term capital gains, short-term capital gain dividends paid by the Fund from net short-term capital gains and interest-related dividends paid by the Fund from its qualified net interest income from U.S. sources. However, notwithstanding such exemptions from U.S. withholding tax at source, any such dividends and distributions of income and capital gains will be subject to backup withholding at a rate of 24% if you fail to properly certify that you are not a U.S. person.

Other reporting and withholding requirements: Payments to a shareholder that is either a foreign financial institution or a non-financial foreign entity within the meaning of the Foreign Account Tax Compliance Act (FATCA) may be subject to a 30% withholding tax on income dividends paid by the Fund. The FATCA withholding tax generally can be avoided by such foreign entity if it provides the Fund, and in some cases, the IRS, information concerning the ownership of certain foreign financial accounts or other appropriate certifications or documentation concerning its status under FATCA. The Fund may be required to report certain shareholder account information to the IRS, non-U.S. taxing authorities or other parties to comply with FATCA.

Other tax information: This discussion of “Distributions and Taxes” is for general information only and is not tax advice. You should consult your own tax advisor regarding your particular circumstances, and about any federal, state, local and foreign tax consequences before making an investment in the Fund. Additional information about the tax consequences of investing in the Fund may be found in the SAI.

V. Performance, Reporting, and Technical

1. Provide historical performance relative to the most relevant benchmark and explanations for any deviations from the benchmark

As of August 31, 2024, the Fund’s average annual total return since inception (April 4, 2021) is 2.97%, 3.37% on a three-year basis, and 5.32% on a 1-year basis. This Fund does not have a benchmark.

2. Describe the frequency, content, and process for performance and portfolio transparency reports. Who provides these?

As an investor, you will receive monthly and quarterly account statements from Franklin Templeton electronically through the Institutional Web Portal that show all your account transactions for the period. You also will receive the Fund’s shareholder reports every six months, which include the Fund’s financial statements. In addition, you will receive an annual updated summary prospectus electronically through the Institutional Web Portal (prospectus available upon request). At any time, you may view current prospectuses/summary prospectuses and shareholder reports through the Institutional Web Portal or online at www.franklintempleton.com/FOBXX. You may also print paper copies of the Fund’s shareholder reports and current prospectus/summary prospectus online at www.franklintempleton.com/FOBXX. This financial statement in the Fund’s annual shareholder report is audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, an independent registered public accounting firm.

3. Describe the accounting and auditing processes for the portfolio and product

As an SEC-registered mutual fund, the Fund has a Board of Trustees, an Audit Committee comprised of Independent Trustees, and the Fund’s financial statements are audited by an independent public accounting firm. As mentioned above, PricewaterhouseCoopers LLP, the Fund’s independent registered public accounting firm, audits the financial statements included in the Fund’s Annual Report to shareholders. To see a copy of this audit report, please visit page 16 of Appendix 4 – Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund Annual Report.

4. Describe the technical implementation of your product

Franklin Templeton’s Digital Asset Technology team pioneered, created, and built our own proprietary blockchain-integrated recordkeeping system that utilizes features of traditional book-entry system and records transactions to one or more public blockchain networks, and this integrated ecosystem is referred to as the Benji platform. The Benji platform allows for the for the minting, burning, transferring, freezing and clawing back of Benji Tokens. The code is tested internally as well as audited by providers shared below. The platform has been demonstrated to the U.S. SEC, Luxembourg CSSF, Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), and the UK FCA on more than one occasion. The tokenization engine is multi-chain and the official transaction records are on-chain. The blockchain protocols Franklin Templeton supports are Stellar, Polygon, Arbitrum, Avalanche and Ethereum. In addition, we are working on the deployment of Aptos, Solana and Base. Other networks are evaluated regularly and go through an assessment of suitability based on specific criteria. The current U.S. Fund is available to individual or institutional investors that purchase shares directly from the Fund through the Benji Mobile App (for retail investors) or Benji Institutional Web Portal (as applicable). Similar to traditional fund recordkeeping systems, all Fund and shareholder records in the blockchain-integrated system are under the full and complete control of the Fund’s transfer agent.

5. What audits have been performed on the smart contracts involved with your product, by whom, and when?

Our smart contract code has been audited by Trail of Bits as of September 2023. A detailed report can be accessed here. Updates to our smart contact code were made in May 2024 and audited by Ancilia. A detailed report can be accessed here.

VI. MakerDAO Ecosystem

1. Describe any previous relationship with MakerDAO and familiarity working with DAOs

Prior to MakerDAO’s Endgame implementation, we proposed that a portion of MakerDAO’s treasury to be allocated to the BENJI Token. To read more about our proposal from April 2023, please visit our MIP here. In addition, our team has relationships with some of the largest Decentralized Autonomous Organizations (DAOs) in the digital asset ecosystem. Currently in our Digital Asset Investment portfolios, we own several governance tokens including many of the top governance tokens by market cap.

2. Beyond yield, how might your product benefit the SparkDAO and/or MakerDAO ecosystem?

The BENJI Token provides SparkDAO and MakerDAO access to the first U.S. registered Fund whose transaction records live natively on public blockchains, which can enhance the DAO’s treasury transparency, diversification and liquidity through a stable, regulatory compliant product. Additionally, we are actively working on expanding both the features of the BENJI Token, such as self-custody through your preferred wallet provider, which is currently available for Institutional clients, and extending its functionality across additional blockchain networks.

We envision numerous applications for the BENJI Token across both the digital asset ecosystem and traditional finance. We believe peer-to-peer transfers have the potential to enhance the corporate funding process, whether that’s through Venture Capital firms who want to fund new projects or existing portfolio companies through a yield-bearing asset, or even for DAOs like Spark who may want to give grant funding to their sub-DAOs or other projects building on their native chain. In addition, we believe the BENJI Token may be able to provide utility for payments or even as a settlement or collateral token, since holders can engage in peer-to-peer transfers between each other between networks for any purpose.

3. Does the product have integrations with any other platforms?

The Fund currently uses the Stellar network as the primary public blockchain and Fund investors will initially hold their wallets on the Stellar network. However, the Fund may also use other blockchain networks, including Polygon, Aptos, Avalanche, Arbitrum, Ethereum, Solana, and Base for certain accounts upon request and subject to eligibility, although one or more of those other blockchain networks may not be available at certain times. Please stay tuned for additional network availability.

Fund shares may be transferred in peer-to-peer transactions from one shareholder wallet to another shareholder wallet (or potential shareholder wallet) within any approved blockchain network or between any two approved blockchain networks. Shares of the Fund may be transferred using the Institutional Web Portal. A complete record of these transactions is viewable on the blockchain due to being recorded by the transfer agent’s blockchain-integrated recordkeeping system. Before transferring Fund shares, you (as the transferor) and the potential transferee must each have an active, permissioned (i.e., “whitelisted”) wallet registered with the Fund’s transfer agent on any approved blockchain network. You may use the Institutional Web Portal to authorize the transfer agent to transfer your shares to a transferee that you identify using the public key for the transferee’s wallet. There is no minimum number of shares required to process a transfer. The transfer agent is responsible for ensuring that the potential transferee in a peer-to-peer transaction has a permissioned wallet on an approved blockchain network.

  • Although you may provide instructions to transfer Fund shares at any time, transfers are processed at the Fund’s next NAV calculation time after we receive your transfer request in proper form through the Institutional Web Portal.
  • Notwithstanding the fact that the Fund processes peer-to-peer transfers after the next calculated NAV following the receipt of a transfer request in proper form, the Fund does not require that peer-to-peer transfers occur at NAV.
  • A whitelisted investor must be aware of other whitelisted investors who are available to enter into peer-to-peer transfers and neither the Fund nor its transfer agent will play any role in connecting transferors and transferees.
  • Peer-to-peer transfers do not constitute a public trading market and Fund shares will not be listed for trading on any such market, including a national securities exchange or an alternative trading system operating by a registered broker that is subject to Regulation ATS.
  • To the extent investors engage in peer-to-peer transfers at a price other than NAV, such transfers may, in certain circumstances, have legal implications for those investors under the federal securities laws or otherwise.
  • The transfer agent cannot ensure the reliability of any transfer of other assets negotiated in connection with peer-to-peer transfers other than transfers of Fund shares that a shareholder instructs the transfer agent to make.
  • Blockchain network(s) on which a peer-to-peer transfer is recorded may impose transaction fees to validate the transaction on the network. These fees are typically paid in the native digital asset for the operation of the blockchain network and will be the responsibility of the investment manager or its affiliates; Fund investors will not be required to purchase any native digital asset to transact on the network.
    You should consult your own tax advisor regarding your particular circumstances, and about any federal, state, local and foreign tax consequences in connection with the transfer of Fund shares.

4. Do you offer or plan to offer other products that could be appropriate for Spark or other SubDAOs?

As previously mentioned, the Franklin Templeton Digital Assets team offers a variety of digital asset investment strategies, from multi-coin portfolios to single asset ETFs or private vehicles. Our investment team can also build customized multi-coin portfolios based on an investor’s desired risk tolerance and investment goals. Our digital asset investment team is open to any conversations on our product offerings should there be interest from Spark or other SubDAOs of Maker.

We have also mentioned that Franklin Templeton provides over 200+ investment strategies across a full range of vehicles and investment strategies. We are happy to facilitate connections for SparkDAO if there is interest in any of our traditional products.

References: Due to posting limitations, we will follow up with the following Appendix Items over email.

  • Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund Prospectus
  • Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund SAI
  • Franklin Templeton Corporate Governance Documents
  • Appendix 1 – Say Hello to Benji
  • Appendix 2 – Franklin Advisers, Inc. Regulatory Summary
  • Appendix 3 – Franklin Advisers, Inc. 5-Year Litigation Summary
  • Appendix 4 – Franklin OnChain U.S. Government Money Fund Annual Report

item.title: Sky Protocol Launch Success
item.dc:creator: ecosystem-team
item.description:
Dear Community,
We’re thrilled to announce that the launch of Sky Protocol has been successfully completed. This marks a significant milestone in our journey, and we couldn’t be more proud of the hard work and dedication shown by all teams involved.

We’d like to extend our heartfelt congratulations to everyone who contributed to this achievement - from our development teams to our marketing, legal, and operations staff. Your tireless efforts and commitment have brought us to this momentous day.

As we move forward, we’re excited to see how the Sky Protocol will grow and evolve. We encourage all community members to explore the new features and provide feedback as the teams continue to refine and expand the offerings.

Thank you for your ongoing support and trust in the Sky Protocol. Here’s to a bright future ahead!

item.title: Sky Risk & Analytics Dashboard Announcement
item.dc:creator: rema
item.description:
Introduction

Since 2021, @BA-Labs has been actively contributing to the Sky Ecosystem through the development and maintenance of user-friendly and open dashboards. We initially supported the legacy Maker system through the Maker Risk Dashboard and Makerburn. Following the launch of SparkLend, we extended our support to Spark users through the Spark Risk Dashboard.

After more than a year of development, we are now excited to announce the launch of the Sky Risk & Analytics Dashboard.

Sky Risk & Analytics Dashboard is available on the following URL: https://info.sky.money

The Sky Risk & Analytics Dashboard was designed with two main goals in mind: providing a simple user experience while at the same time highlighting the resilience of the Sky Ecosystem. The motivation behind these design principles are based on the assumption that a protocol’s risk management is only as effective as its ability to clearly present risk metrics to protocol users, regardless of their knowledge or experience level. Our aim is for the Sky Risk & Analytics Dashboard to become the new standard, where all Sky stakeholders can easily digest data regarding the most critical aspects of the Sky Protocol and broader Sky Ecosystem.

Below, we highlight some of the key features that make the new dashboard an important tool for Sky Ecosystem participants.

Homepage

The Sky Risk & Analytics Dashboard homepage is intended to provide insights into the holistic performance of the Sky Ecosystem. Below, we explain the meaning of each individual widget on this page.

  • Rewards TVL & Savings TVL: The widgets at the top of the homepage present current Sky Rewards TVL and Savings TVL. For both metrics, an APY counter is also included.
  • Upgrade Progress Tracker: Below the TVL widgets, we have included an Upgrade Progress Tracker for both USDS and SKY. On the left side of the Upgrade Progress Tracker, the dashboard tracks the amount of DAI which has been upgraded to USDS. On the right side of the Upgrade Progress Tracker, the dashboard tracks the amount of MKR which has been upgraded to SKY.
  • Total Supply: Total Supply is an aggregate metric, consisting of all DAI and USDS supply in the Sky Ecosystem.
  • Surplus: This widget allows users to check the current system-level surplus. By clicking on the Surplus widget, the user is taken to a Surplus page, where more specific information is available.
  • Collateralization: The Collateralization widget shows the total dollar-denominated value of collateral which is being used to borrow DAI and USDS.
  • Smart Burn Engine: On the homepage, the Smart Burn Engine widget displays the total amount of dollar-denominated liquidity owned by the Sky Ecosystem. If the user clicks on the widget, the dashboard will show more detailed information, such as the amount of SKY & USDS tokens owned, impermanent loss/profit, historical metrics, and historical activity.
  • Estimated Annual Net Revenue: This widget shows the estimated annual net revenue, assuming that protocol parameters, such as stability fees, liquidations penalties, PSM fees, and expenses remain constant.
  • USDS Diversification Donut Chart: On the bottom-right side of the homepage, we have included a donut chart to illustrate the USDS diversification throughout the Sky Ecosystem. It is possible to click on individual sections within the donut chart to see more detailed information regarding each USDS allocation.
  • USDS & SKY Widgets: Finally, at the bottom of the page, we have included two widgets regarding USDS and SKY, displaying dollar-denominated price, token supply, and market capitalization. By clicking on these widgets, the user is able to retrieve more granular information, including historical activity, number of holders, and holder distribution.

Dashboard Menu

By clicking on the menu item in the top right corner of the dashboard interface, the dashboard menu pops up. Here, we have included some of the most important dashboard pages for easier navigation. Below, we go through each menu item in further detail.

Collateral

The Collateral page is intended to provide a high-level overview of current collateral and debt distributions throughout the Sky Ecosystem. At the top of the page, we have included aggregated metrics for total debt, total collateral, as well as the system-wide collateralization ratio. Below, we have included a simple table where we list each USDS deployment and provide information regarding debt, collateral, collateral ratio, and estimated annual net revenue from each location.

Tokens

With the Sky Token and Product Launch, a number of new tokens have been introduced, while the legacy MKR and DAI tokens will continue to be supported. Recognizing that some users may find it complicated to track these changes, we have dedicated an entire page to clearly separate and display relevant metrics for each token in the Sky Ecosystem. At the time of writing, the page tracks DAI, MKR, sDAI, USDS, SKY, and sUSDS. The overview table provides four key metrics for each token: (i) dollar-denominated price, (ii) supply, (iii) market capitalization, and (iv) holders. It is also possible to click on each row to navigate to token specific pages with more granular data.

Liquidations

Native Vaults remain a critical component of the Sky Ecosystem. To ensure a healthy liquidation system and the prevention of bad debt, it is important to maintain a page with transparent liquidation data. The Liquidations page in the Sky Risk & Analytics Dashboard aims to display relevant liquidations metrics on both a protocol-wide level, as well as for each individual Vault.

Rewards

One of the key upgrades of the new Sky Ecosystem is the Rewards system. To support this upgrade, we have included a page where users can track data related to Sky Token Rewards (STR), as well as the upcoming Activation Rewards and Sealed Activation Rewards.

Savings

Another important feature of the Sky Ecosystem is the Sky Savings Rate (SSR). The Savings page provides detailed metrics regarding (i) the total supply within the SSR, (ii) the current Savings Rate, and (iii) SSR utilization. Additionally, as long as the DSR remains active, we will continue to monitor and display relevant metrics for it on the same page.

Parameters

For risk analysts, governance participants, and other ecosystem stakeholders, the ability to monitor current protocol risk parameters is an important part of the Sky Governance process. To address this need, we have developed a dedicated page that includes all relevant risk parameters, auction parameters, and a historical record of parameter changes.

Protocol Finances

The Revenue page showcases Sky’s estimated annual net revenue, assuming that protocol parameters, such as Stability Fees (SFs), liquidation penalties, PSM fees, as well as expenses, remain constant.

Glossary

If a user encounters a metric or data point which is unfamiliar, they can refer to the dedicated Glossary page to learn more about the Sky Ecosystem.

Future Dashboard Improvements

Our team will continue to develop and improve the Sky Risk & Analytics Dashboard as the Sky Ecosystem progresses, both during Launch Season and subsequent phases of the Sky Ecosystem evolution. We plan to integrate additional information as new features are introduced to the Sky Protocol. These include:

  • More detailed information regarding tokens and token emissions
  • Support for Activation Rewards and Sealed Activation Rewards
  • A more detailed page for Sealed Activation metrics
  • Support for Skylink
  • More detailed information regarding Spark once the Spark Star launches

We will update the Sky community on a monthly cadence by reporting relevant updates and improvements through the Risk Month in Review series. Finally, we value any questions or comments regarding the Sky Risk & Analytics Dashboard. If you have any questions, please add comments below or get in touch directly with members of @BA-Labs.
